notes_post: <virtūs, virtūtis> virtue f.
<nōmen, nōminis> name n.

t12.title: Third declension special rules: Parisyllabic rule,	Double consonant rule,	Special neuter ending

t13.title: Third declension Irregular nouns
notes_pre: 1. Here <ō> or <ū> come from Old Latin ou. Thus <bō>-/<bū>- and <Iū>- before consonant endings are alternate developments of the <bov>- and <Iov>- before vowel endings. — The double <pp> in the preferred form <Iu>-<ppiter> "Father Jove" is an alternate way of marking the length of the <u> in the etymological form <Iū>-<piter>. i is weakened from <a> in <pater> (Allen and Greenough, sect. 79 b).
2. Genitive and dative singular cases are seldom used in vīs.

t25.title: Second person singular possessive pronoun: <tuus>
notes_pre: <tuus, tua, tuum> your, yours (for singular possessor)

t26.title: Third person reflexive possessive pronoun: <suus>
notes_pre: <suus, sua, suum> his, her, its, theirs (reflexive)

t31.title: Declension of <īdem>
notes_pre: <īdem, eadem, idem> the same, same as

t38.title: First and second declension pronominal adjectives

t39.title: First- and Second-declension pronominal adjectives: <uter> which (of two), either

t40.title: First- and Second-declension pronominal adjectives: <neuter> neither

t41.title: First- and Second-declension pronominal adjectives: <solus> sole, alone

t42.title: First- and Second-declension pronominal adjectives: <alius> another
notes_post: The genitive singular <alīus> is often replaced by <alterīus> or by <aliēnus> "of another".

t43.title: First- and Second-declension pronominal adjectives: <totus> whole

t44.title: First- and Second-declension pronominal adjectives: <alter> other (of two)

t46.title: First and second declension -r adjectives without contractions

t47.title: First and second declension -r adjectives with contractions

t53.title: General pattern for comparative of adjectives

t54.title: General pattern for superlative adjectives
notes_pre: <altissimus, altissima, altissimum> - highest, deepest (superlative of altus)

t57.title: Irregular comparative and superlative adjectives
notes_pre: [i] <plūs>: Noun used with genitive to express more of something in the singular; in the plural used as an adjective: <plūrēs, plūra>, genitive <plūrium>.
[ii] <mātūrrimus>: Often replaced by the regular form <mātūrissimus, mātūrissima, mātūrissimum>.
[iv] <minimus nātū>: Sometimes <iunissimus> is found in medieval Latin, e.g. Callistus Nicephorus, Ecclesiastica Historia, 1574.

t58.title: Adverbs from first and second declension adjectives

t61.title: Irregular adverbs with peculiar comparative and superlative forms.

t62.title: First conjugation active indicative verb
notes_pre: In early Latin (Plautus), the 3rd singular endings -<at> and -<et> were pronounced -<āt> and -<ēt> with a long vowel.

t64.title: first conjugation passive indicative verb
notes_pre: The 2nd person singular passive <amāberis, amābāris, amēris, amārēris> can be shortened to <amābere, amābāre, amēre, amārēre>. -<re> was the regular form in early Latin and (except in the present indicative) in Cicero; -<ris> was preferred later.

t66.title: Perfect tenses: first conjugation active indicative verb
notes_pre: In poetry (and also sometimes in prose, e.g. Livy), the 3rd person plural of the perfect indicative is often <amāvēre> instead of <amāvērunt>. Occasionally the form <amāverunt> is also found.
The -v- of the perfect active tenses sometimes drops out, especially in the pluperfect subjunctive: <amāssem> for <amāvissem>. Forms such as <amārat> and <amāstī> are also found.

t67.title: Perfect tenses: first conjugation active subjunctive

t68.title: Perfect tenses: first conjugation passive indicative

t70.title: Second conjugation active indicative verb
notes_pre: The second conjugation is characterized by the vowel <ē>, and can be recognized by the -<eō> ending of the first person present indicative and the -<ēre> ending of the present active infinitive form.
In verbs with perfect in -<vī>, syncopated (i.e. abbreviated) forms are common, such as <dēlēram>, <dēlēssem>, <dēlēstī> for <dēlēveram>, <dēlēvissem>, <dēlēvistī>.

t74.title: Third conjugation active indicative verb
notes_pre: The third conjugation has a variable short stem vowel, which may be e, i, or u in different environments. Verbs of this conjugation end in -<ere> in the present active infinitive. Deponent verbs have the infinitive -<ī>.
The future tense in the 3rd and 4th conjugation (-<am>, -<ēs>, -<et> etc.) differs from that in the 1st and 2nd conjugation (-<bō>, -<bis>, -<bit> etc.).
Four 3rd conjugation verbs usually have no ending in the imperative singular: <dūc>! "lead!", <dīc>! "say!", <fer>! "bring!", <fac>! "do!".

t78.title: Third conjugation active indicative verb
notes_pre: Intermediate between the third and fourth conjugation are the third-conjugation verbs with suffix –<iō>. These resemble the fourth conjugation in some forms.

t82.title: Fourth conjugation active indicative verb
notes_pre: The fourth conjugation is characterized by the vowel ī and can be recognized by the -<īre> ending of the present active infinitive. Deponent verbs have the infinitive -<īrī>.

In the perfect tenses, shortened forms without -<v>- are common, for example, <audīstī, audiērunt, audierat, audīsset> for <audīvistī, audīvērunt, audīverat, audīvisset>. Cicero, however, prefers the full forms <audīvī, audīvit> to <audiī>, audiit.

t87.title: Irregular verb subjunctive: <sum> to be
notes_pre: In early Latin (e.g. Plautus), <siem, siēs, siēt> can be found for the present subjunctive <sim, sīs, sit>. In poetry the subjunctive <fuam, fuās, fuat> also sometimes occurs.
An alternative imperfect subjunctive is sometimes made using <forem, forēs, foret> etc.

t88.title: Irregular verb indicative: <possum> (<pot> + <esse>) to be able to

t89.title: Irregular verb subjunctive: <possum> (<pot> + <esse>) to be able to / can

t98.title: Irregular verb active indicative: <fero> (bring, bear, carry)
notes_pre: The verb <ferō, ferre, tulī, lātum> "to bring, to bear, to carry" is 3rd conjugation, but irregular in that the vowel following the root <fer-> is sometimes omitted. The perfect tense <tulī> and supine stem <lātum> are also irregularly formed.

t99.title: Irregular verb active subjunctive: <fero> (bring, bear, carry)

t100.title: Irregular verb passive indicative: <fero> (bring, bear, carry)

t101.title: Irregular verb passive subjunctive: <fero> (bring, bear, carry)

t102.title: Irregular verb indicative active: <fiō>
notes_pre: The irregular verb <fīō, fierī, factus sum> "to become, to happen, to be done, to be made" as well as being a verb in its own right serves as the passive of <faciō, facere, fēcī, factum> "to do, to make". The perfect tenses are identical with the perfect passive tenses of <faciō>.
The 1st and 2nd plural forms are almost never found.

t107.title: Infinitive of regular verbs (with masculine endings used for participles)

t109.title: Gerund of regular verbs
notes_pre: The gerund is formed similarly to the present active participle. However, the -<ns> becomes an -<ndus>, and the preceding <ā> or <ē> is shortened. Gerunds are neuter nouns of the second declension, but the nominative case is not present. The gerund is a noun, meaning "the act of doing (the verb)", and forms a suppletive paradigm to the infinitive, which cannot be declined. For example, the genitive form <laudandī> can mean "of praising", the dative form <laudandō> can mean "for praising", the accusative form <laudandum> can mean "praising", and the ablative form <laudandō> can mean "by praising", "in respect to praising", etc.

One common use of the gerund is with the preposition ad to indicate purpose. For example, <paratus ad oppugnandum> could be translated as "ready to attack". However the gerund was avoided when an object was introduced, and a passive construction with the gerundive was preferred. For example, for "ready to attack the enemy" the construction <paratus ad hostes oppugnandos> is preferred over <paratus ad hostes oppugnandum>.

t110.title: Gerundive of regular verbs
notes_pre: The gerundive has a form similar to that of the gerund, but it is a first and second declension adjective, and functions as a future passive participle. It means "(which is) to be ...ed". Often, the gerundive is used with part of the verb <esse>, to show obligation.

t111.title: Active periphrastic tenses
notes_pre: The first periphrastic conjugation uses the future participle. It is combined with the forms of <esse>. It is translated as "I am going to praise," "I was going to praise", etc.
data: I will be going to praise
I have been going to praise
I had been going to praise
I will have been going to praise
I may be going to praise
I should be going to praise
I may have been going to praise
I should have been going to praise

t112.title: Passive periphrastic tenses
notes_pre: The second periphrastic conjugation uses the gerundive. It is combined with the forms of esse and expresses necessity. It is translated as "I am needing to be praised", "I was needing to be praised", etc., or as "I have to (must) be praised", "I had to be praised," etc.
data: I am needing to be praised
I was needing to be praised
I will be needing to be praised
I was needing to be praised
I had been needing to be praised
I will have been needing to be praised
I may be needing to be praised
I should be needing to be praised
I may have been needing to be praised
I should have been needing to be praised
To be needing to be praised
To have been needing to be praised

t113.title: Conjugation of defective verb <aiō>
notes_post: Present Active Participle: – <aiēns, aientis>

t117.title: Impersonal verbs
notes_pre: Impersonal verbs are those lacking a person. In English impersonal verbs are usually used with the neuter pronoun "it" (as in "It seems," or "it is raining"). Latin uses the third person singular. These verbs lack a fourth principal part. A few examples are:
data: to be proper (it is proper, one should/ought to)

t118.title: Irregular future active participles
notes_pre: The future active participle is normally formed by removing the –<um> from the supine, and adding a –<ūrus>. However, some deviations occur.

t123.title: Distributive numbers 1-20
notes_pre: Another set of n'l adjectives, similar to the above but differing in the adjectives for 1, 3, and 4, were the distributive numerals: <singulī, bīnī, ternī, quaternī, quīnī, sēnī>, and so on. The meaning of these is "one each", "two each" (or "in pairs") and so on.

t125.title: Adverbial numbers 1-20
notes_pre: Adverbial numerals are (as the name states) indeclinable adverbs, but because all of the other numeral constructions are adjectives, they are listed here with them. Adverbial numerals give how many times a thing happened. <semel> "once", <bis> "twice", <ter> "thrice, three times", <quater> "four times", and so on.
notes_post: The suffix <-iēns> may also be spelled <-iēs>: <quinquiēs, sexiēs>, etc. E.g. <equidem deciēs dīxī> (Plautus) "indeed I"ve said it ten times already"

t127.title: Proportional numbers 1-20
notes_pre: Proportional numerals are declinable adjectives. <simplus> "simple", <duplus> "twice as great", <triplus> "thrice as great", <quadruplus> "four times as great", and so on.
notes_post: These are often used as nouns: <simplum> "the simple sum", <duplum> "double the amount of money" and so on. E.g. <duplam pecūniam in thēsaurōs repōnī> (Livy) "double the amount of money to be replaced in the treasuries"

t133.title: Cardinal numbers: centum hundred
notes_pre: The numeral centum ("one hundred") is indeclinable, but all the other hundred numerals are declinable (<ducentī, trecentī, quadringentī, quīngentī, sescentī, septingentī, octingentī, nōngentī>).

t135.title: Syntax: Sequence of Tenses in Indirect Questions & Cum clauses
notes_post: [1.i] Used with the indicative, the conjunction <cum> means "at that time when", or "whenever": <cum tacent, clāmant> (Cicero) —"when they are silent, (it is as if) they are shouting"
[1.ii] Used with the subjunctive, however, <cum> frequently means "at a time when".

[1.iii] When <cum> is used with the Imperfect subjunctive, a common way of translating it is "while": <cum sedērem domī trīstis, accurrit Venerius> (Cicero) — "while I was sitting sadly at home, Venerius suddenly came running up"

(1.iv] With the Pluperfect subjunctive, <cum> often means "after X happened": <cum excessisset Aegyptō Antiochus, lēgātī ... Cyprum nāvigant> (Livy) — "after Antiochus had left Egypt, the ambassadors sailed to Cyprus"
[1.v] <Cum> can also mean "in view of the fact that" or "since": <quae cum ita sint> "in view of the fact that these things are so" / "since this is so"

[1.vi] Another, less common, meaning of <cum> is "though" (often with <tamen> in the <cum>-clause): <nihil mē adiūvit, cum posset> (Cicero) — "he did nothing to help me, though (or: at a time when) he could have done"

[2] In later Latin, quod with the subjunctive could substitute for the accusative and infinitive in indirect statement, though this did not become common until the second century AD: <et vīdit Deus quod esset bonum> (Vulgate Bible) — "and God saw that it was good"

[3] Indirect questions expecting an answer yes or no can be introduced by <-ne> (<an>) or <num> ("whether", "if"): <quaesīvit ā mē vellemne sēcum in castra proficīscī> (Nepos) — "he asked me whether I wanted to go with him to the camp"; <pecūniam admōvit ad nārēs, scīscitāns num odōre offenderētur> (Suetonius) — "he held the money under Titus's nose, asking if he was offended by the smell"

[4] Most verbs of ordering, persuading, and encouraging are followed by <ut> (<utī>) "that" or <nē> "that not" and a subjunctive mood verb. This construction is common after verbs such as <imperō> "I order", <rogō> "I ask", <petō> "I request", <moneō> "I advise", <persuādeō> "I persuade", <hortor> "I exhort" and others.
[5] There is no future periphrastic form for the passive; use the present/imperfect and an adverb e.g. <cras>.

t136.title: Syntax: Sequence of Tenses in Indirect Statements (accusative and infinitive pattern)
notes_post: [1] One verb, <sum> "I am" has its own future infinitive <fore>, which may be used instead of <futūrum esse>. The verb <possum> "I am able" on the other hand has no future infinitive or future participle.

[2] The future participle combined with <fuisse>, which expresses a past or present potential ("would be doing" or "would have done"): <nisī dē viā fessus esset, continuō ad nōs ventūrum fuisse> (Cicero) — "(he said that) if he had not been tired from the journey, he would have come to us straightaway"

[3] The infinitive is used only for the main verb in an indirect statement; any other verbs are changed into the subjunctive mood, using one of the past tenses if the context is past: <locum ubi esset facile inventūrōs> (Nepos) — "(he told them that) they would easily find the place where he was"

[4] The main verb introducing indirect statements does not have to be a verb of speaking; it can also be any of a range of other verbs, such as <sēnsit> "he realised", <simulāvit> "he pretended", <cōnstat> "it is well known", <spērō> "I hope", <scrīpsit> "he wrote" and so on, which use the same construction.

[5] Some verbs, principally the verb <iubeō> "I order" and its opposite <vetō> "I forbid", use the accusative and infinitive construction, often with a passive infinitive: <signum darī iubet> (Caesar) — "he ordered the signal to be given"
data: They say he is/they are helping her.
They say he/they would help her.

t137.title: Syntax: Main Latin Tense Forms Overview
notes_post: The difference between the two sets of perfect tenses is sometimes one of time, the second set referring to an earlier time than the first, as in this example from Caesar which contains both kinds: <pōns, quī fuerat tempestāte interruptus, paene erat refectus> — "the bridge, which earlier on had been broken by a storm, had now almost been rebuilt"

t139.title: Syntax: conditional (if) clauses with open, ideal & unreal conditions. (Protasis & apodosis)
notes_pre: Conditional clauses in Latin are clauses which start with the conjunction <sī> "if" or the equivalent. The if-clause in a conditional sentence is known as the protasis, and the consequence is called the apodosis.

Conditional clauses are generally divided into three types: open conditions, when the truth of the condition is unknown ("if it is true that…"); ideal conditions, in which the speaker imagines a situation or event which might occur in the future ("if this were to happen…"); and unreal conditions, referring to an event or situation in the present or past known to be contrary to fact ("if it were true that…"). These three are also sometimes referred to as Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3 respectively.

Open conditional clauses in turn can be divided into particular and general. Open conditional sentences generally use the indicative mood in both protasis and apodosis, although in some general conditions the subjunctive mood is used in the protasis. Ideal and unreal conditionals use the subjunctive in the protasis, and usually they also use the subjunctive in the apodosis, though sometimes the indicative may be used. Conditional clauses of comparison ("as if") also use the subjunctive mood in the protasis.

The conjunction <sī> is only rarely used in classical Latin to introduce indirect questions, although this usage is found in medieval Latin. The use of "if" to make a wish, found in ancient Greek, is not usual in Latin, except sometimes in poetry.
A difference from English grammar is that in open future conditions, it is usual in Latin to use one of the future tenses, when English has the present tense.
notes_post: Positive conditions are shown by: <sīn> "but if" ( used for the second of two opposite conditions); <sīve ... sīve> (or Livy's preferred form: <seu ... seu>) "whether ... or"; <quod sī> "but if" or "if, however" can also introduce an alternative; <etsī, etiamsī (…tamen)> "although"; <etiam sī> (or <etiamsī>) "even if", "even though"; <siquidem> or <sī quidem> means "if indeed" or "if it's true that"; <sī modō> "if indeed" expresses doubt that the situation mentioned is in fact true; <sī quis>  "if anyone", <sī quid> "if anything", <sī quī>  "if any", <sī quisquam> "if anyone at all", <sī quicquam> "if anything at all", <sī quandō> "if at any time / if ever",  <sī quā> "if in any way".
When the conditional clause is negative, there are various possibilities: <nisi> "if not/unless", <sī ... nōn> "if not",  <nī> "were it not that" and <sī minus> "otherwise".
data: If it were to have happened
